awd_titl_txt: Synergy between oxide and nitride phases of a novel composite cathode for high-temperature electrocatalytic NH3 synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on a strategy for producing ammonia from N2 and H2O electrocatalytically at atmospheric pressure. The conventional route for ammonia (NH3) production is the Haber-Bosch (HB) process, which involves converting nitrogen and hydrogen through a thermo-catalytic reaction at high temperatures and high pressures. The demand for ammonia has been continuously increasing due to its widespread use in several industrial sectors including agriculture (approximately 80% of the produced ammonia is used to make fertilizer), transportation, pharmaceuticals, explosives, as well as the energy sector as a promising indirect hydrogen storage medium. Considering the increasing demand for NH3 and the highly energy-intensive nature of the conventional process with significant CO2 emissions, a cleaner and less energy-intensive alternative will have a significant economic and environmental impact. In addition, this project has the potential to provide new insights into the material synthesis and characterization, the mechanistic steps and the electro-catalytic phenomena, which can be translated to other catalytic and electrocatalytic systems for environmentally-important processes such as electrocatalytic reduction of NOx and CO2 electrolysis.  Research activities proposed here will be integrated with established education and outreach programs at the Ohio State University with the ultimate goal of increasing student participation, retention and graduation in STEM fields.  

The overall goal of the project is to develop highly active and selective cathode electro-catalysts for the high-temperature electrosynthesis of ammonia in solid oxide electrolysis cell (SOEC)-type reactors. The high-temperature (400-600 degrees C) electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis will involve dissociation of H2O to form H+ and O2- and the electrocatalytic activation of N2, followed by reaction with H+ to form NH3. In this scheme, O2- ions are conducted through the oxide ion conducting electrolyte to the anode, where they form molecular oxygen.  In this study, we will examine a composite cathode system which is composed of perovskite oxides and metallic/bimetallic nitride/oxynitrides and we will investigate the synergy between these phases. The rationale of using a composite system is that the perovskite oxide phase will catalyze the H2O dissociation and provide oxide ion and electronic conductivity while the nitride/oxynitride phase will promote the N2 activation and provide nitrogen ion mobility. To the best of our knowledge, such a synergistic effect has never been reported before. Our approach to study the high-temperature electrocatalytic production of ammonia concept and to investigate an oxide/nitride composite cathode for this purpose will involve an iterative process of material synthesis, ex-situ/in-situ/operando characterization and electrocatalytic activity tests. The knowledge gained in this project will help open up a new route ammonia synthesis from N2 and H2O. It will also help develop similar electrolysis/electrocatalytic cells for environmentally-important processes such as electrocatalytic reduction of NOx and co-electrolysis of CO2 and H2O for syngas production. In addition to its potential contribution to the high-temperature electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis literature, the proposed study has significant potential to provide valuable insights in electrocatalysis, materials synthesis, surface chemistry and kinetics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to develop a novel electrode system capable of activating both water and nitrogen molecules electrocatalytically for the production of ammonia from nitrogen and water at atmospheric pressure. The high-temperature electrocatalytic route proposed in this study promises to offer a less energy-intensive, more economically feasible, and environmentally friendlier alternative to conventional ammonia production process, the Haber-Bosch process.

The significance of this research lies in its potential to revolutionize scalable on-site ammonia production. Currently, ammonia is produced on a large scale through the Haber-Bosch process, which requires high temperatures (400-500°C), high pressures (150-300 atm), and a hydrogen feed stream, consuming large amounts of energy and releasing significant amounts of CO2. In contrast, the electrocatalytic production of ammonia in small-scale and on-site using N2 and H2O at atmospheric pressure could dramatically reduce energy consumption, lower costs, and minimize environmental impact. By eliminating the need for high-pressure conditions and relying on water as the feedstock, this innovative approach could lead to a more sustainable and scalable method for ammonia synthesis.

In this project, our main objectives were (1) development of an efficient composite cathode system for high-temperature electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis, and (2) gaining a fundamental understanding of the structure-reactivity relationship of perovskite oxides (oxide phase of the composite cathode) and metal nitrides/oxynitrides (nitride phase) under electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis (nitrogen reduction reaction: NRR) conditions.

In the scope of this project, lanthanum ferrite-type perovskites and iron nitride/oxynitride (Fe3N) and bimetallic Fe3Mo3N and Co3Mo3N-type nitrides/oxynitrides as the oxide and nitride phase of the composite cathode, respectively, were synthesized, characterized and tested under electrocatalytic NRR conditions. We systematically studied the interaction between these two phases (oxide and nitride) of the composite cathode to understand the mechanisms of enhanced catalytic performance. The resulting synergy was expected to improve the efficiency and selectivity of ammonia production in electrocatalytic processes. Since the nitride phase is responsible for the activation of nitrogen molecules, i.e. the main active site for the electrocatalytic NRR process, the nitride/oxynitride samples synthesized for this project were characterized in detail. The main observations from these characterization experiments were that (1) the amount and strength of the nitrogen ions in the oxynitride structure is a function of both ammonolysis temperature and duration, (2) the nitrogen ions in the oxynitride structure are mobile and highly active in the presence of H2 and H2O, and (3) the metallic/bimetallic oxynitrides exhibit a core-shell type structure with an oxynitride shell and a mostly nitride core. The electrocatalytic activity tests showed a comparable activity when single metal and bimetallic oxynitrides were used as the nitride phase of the composite cathode and the activity of the composite cathodes was nearly 200 times higher than that of perovskite (oxide-phase only) cathodes.

The project successfully demonstrated the viability of a composite cathode system that achieves high ammonia production efficiency under atmospheric pressure and elevated temperatures. This system represents a promising alternative to traditional ammonia synthesis methods.

This project led to filing of a patent titled “Materials for ammonia synthesis” with an assigned US patent number: US Patent 12,012,662, 2024. The patent is related to the composite cathode design and the electrocatalytic process for ammonia synthesis. The patent outlines the novel approach to ammonia production and the unique synergistic properties of the oxide and nitride phases of the composite cathode.

The results of this research were published in several peer-reviewed journals, detailing the design, synthesis, and performance evaluation of the electrocatalytic system. These publications contribute to the growing body of knowledge in the field of electrocatalysis, materials development, advanced characterization of electrocatalytic materials and sustainable chemical production. Findings from the project were also presented at various international conferences. These presentations facilitated discussions with experts in the field and helped to raise awareness about the potential of high-temperature electrocatalytic ammonia production as a sustainable alternative to the state-of-the-art Haber-Bosch process.

This project also holds a significant environmental impact for reducing the carbon footprint of large-scale ammonia production by eliminating the need for high pressures and pure H2 (product of an energy intensive reforming process) and by offering a small-scale on-site production alternative.

As a conclusion, the project successfully developed a novel electrocatalytic method for ammonia synthesis at atmospheric pressure, offering a promising alternative to conventional, energy-intensive ammonia production process, Haber-Bosch process. Through the development of a composite cathode system, the project demonstrated substantial advancements in electrocatalytic performance and material synergy. The outcomes of this research, including a patent, multiple publications, and conference presentations, contribute to advancing the field of electrocatalysis and highlight the potential of this technology in achieving more sustainable ammonia production.
